urn:contentItem:5S0J-7K41-DXH2-653S-00000-00Cyber Attack Paralyzes Part of Atlanta's Tech Infrastructure; Effect of Excessive Computer Use on Children Examined; Interview with Former Indiana Governor Mitch Daniels; President Trump Proposes Infrastructure Bill; President Trump Criticizes Amazon.2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:23ZLexisNexisFOX SPECIAL REPORT WITH BRET BAIER6:00 PM ESTMitch Daniels, Bill McGurn, Susan Page, Katie Pavlich, David ShulkinNEWSDomestic032901cb.254Cyber Attack Paralyzes Part of Atlanta's Tech Infrastructure; Effect of Excessive Computer Use on Children Examined; Interview with Former Indiana Governor Mitch Daniels; President Trump Proposes Infrastructure Bill; President Trump Criticizes Amazon.Bret Baier, Jonathan Serrie, Lucas Tomlinson, Kevin Corke, Deidre Bolton, Claudia Cowan

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST: Hey, Dana. Thanks.

The outgoing Veterans' Affairs secretary blasts his Washington critics, who he says cost him his job. We'll talk live with Dr. David Shulkin.

President Trump goes after Amazon again, and pushed his public-private partnership to fix America's crumbling infrastructure.

And is your child suffering from the high-tech disorder of too much screen time? Our "Kids and Culture" series continues. This is SPECIAL REPORT.

Good evening, I'm Bret Baier. Just-fired Veterans Affairs Secretary, David Shulkin, is not going quietly tonight. The latest Trump administration to be shown the door is going public with his many grievances. We'll talk with him live in just a moment.

But first, Lucas Tomlinson at the Pentagon on Shulkin's parting shots against the Washington political culture.

Good evening, Lucas.

LUCAS TOMLINSON, FOX CORRESPONDENT: Bret, President Trump used an event in Ohio today to defend the firing of his Veterans Affairs secretary, Dr. David Shulkin.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I wasn't happy with the speed with which our veterans were taken care of. We made changes because we want them taken care of. We want them to have choice so that they can run to a private doctor.

TOMLINSON (voice-over): Shulkin wasn't too happy about getting axed, and took out his frustrations in a blistering op-ed this morning.

Saying, quote, "Washington has turned so toxic, chaotic, disrespectful and subversive that it became impossible for me to accomplish the important work that our veterans need." The former secretary blamed critics for making false accusations against him. "They saw me as an obstacle to privatization."

Calls for the Obama holdover's removal boiled over following an ethics scandal, but Shulkin was quick to point out his successes: expanding access to health care, reducing wait times and working closer with the private sector.

Shulkin says the percentage of veterans who regained trust in the V.A. has risen from 46 percent four years ago to 70 percent today. Still, he struggled to win over Congress and even vets.

SEN. JERRY MORAN (R), KAN.: You led me to believe that you and I were on the same page. Our inability to reach an agreement is in significant part related to your ability to speak out of both sides of your mouth, double- talk.

TOMLINSON (voice-over): Sarah Verardo's (ph) husband has had more than 100 surgeries since being wounded in Afghanistan. She says she's ready for change.

SARAH VERARDO (ph): We need a secretary in there who is empowering and enacting the president's plan. It's a system that needs massive and total overhaul. It's a stain on our nation, and we -- we owe these heroes so much more.

TOMLINSON (voice-over): President Trump's nominee to replace Shulkin, Rear Admiral Ronny Jackson.

ADM. RONNY JACKSON, NOMINEE, U.S. VETERANS AFFAIRS SECRETARY: Some people have, you know, just great genes (ph).

TOMLINSON (voice-over): The White House physician, best known as the doctor who delivered the briefing on President Trump's physical, is already coming under fire for his credentials.

Some question whether the Navy doctor can successfully lead the federal government's second-largest department. The oldest war veterans organization saying, quote, "Doctor JacksonOs bio does not reflect any experience working with the V.A. or with veterans, or managing any organization of this size."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TOMLINSON: On Monday, Acting V.A. Secretary Robert Wilkie takes over on an interim basis. It could be months before Jackson is confirmed -- Bret.

BAIER: Lucas, thank you.

Let's hear directly, now, from Dr. Shulkin. He joins us.

Mr. Secretary, thanks for being here.

DR. DAVID SHULKIN, FORMER U.S. VETERANS AFFAIRS SECRETARY: Glad to be here, Bret.

BAIER: So let's start with this. Why do you think you were fired?

SHULKIN: Well, every cabinet member serves at the pleasure of the president, and it's the president's prerogative to have a team around him that he thinks is doing the job. I think we heard today, from the president, that he wasn't happy with the pace.

And, you know, I agree with the president. This is an organization that needs to change. It needs to do better at its job, and we all want to do it faster and better because it's so important to the country. And I -- I think the president has the right to have the secretary that he wants with him.

BAIER: You said the administration wants to privatize the V.A. Have you ever seen -- we -- we haven't seen evidence of, as far as White House policy directives sent to Congress saying that, is there any direct communication with Congress that the administration wants to privatize the V.A.?

SHULKIN: No, Bret. I actually haven't said that. I'm -- I was part of the administration until yesterday. We are not trying to privatize the V.A. We are trying to improve and transform the V.A.

What I said in my editorial is, is that there are a number of political appointees within V.A. that are pushing to privatize much faster than I think is in the interest of veterans and is the safe way to care for our veterans.

And I've -- I've stood up for them because I was in Washington and I was working for the president on behalf of our veterans.

BAIER: Why did you feel the need to write the op-ed?

SHULKIN: Well, listen, I think it's important. I came to Washington from the private sector for one reason, to fix the V.A. I know this matters a lot to the president. And we as a country have a long way to go to get the V.A. in -- in proper shape.

But it would be a mistake to conclude that we do not need the V.A. and that we have to dismantle the V.A. We have to improve the V.A. while at the same time working with the private sector in an integrated way to meet the needs of our veterans.

BAIER: You know, we heard this sound bite in Lucas' piece from Senator Moran, questioning your dealings with that particular committee. Did -- did you have a credibility issue with Congress?

SHULKIN: Oh, I don't think so. You have to remember, I'm the only cabinet member that had 100 to zero vote. I've prided myself in working in a bipartisan way.

Senator Moran felt strongly about pushing to give veterans additional options that, frankly, his own senators, the committee, didn't agree with. He lost his amendment 14 to one. He was the only one voting against it. And he was frustrated by that.

And, by the way, he had some reasonable points there. So there are many things that he and I agreed upon. But in the end, he didn't like the position that I took, which was to do what I thought was the right thing for our veterans.

BAIER: About 11 months ago, I had you on SPECIAL REPORT. We were talking about the challenges. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Have things changed? Are you seeing change?

SHULKIN: We're in the intensive care unit. And we're monitoring things really closely, but I am optimistic that we're beginning to finally deal with the issues that have plagued the V.A. system for decades.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: So the president said today that he just wasn't happy, how fast or how -- how things were going. That they were going too slowly. What's your response to that, and what can be done to -- to change that pace?

SHULKIN: Well, I don't think the president should be happy with where we were. And as secretary, I wasn't happy with where we were. We have to figure out how to move this bureaucracy faster and be more responsive.

When you showed the Verardos, I know Michael and Sarah very well. And frankly, this was a system that failed them and we shouldn't be doing that. So -- so this is a system that needs to be pushed. Many of the bureaucratic elements need to be restructured. I've started that process. I hope that Dr. Jackson will continue that process because it needs to be done.

BAIER: You know, you had the inspector-general, obviously, come out with this scathing report about -- about your trip to Europe. We -- we've been over that and your response to that. Were there other I.G. investigations or audits that -- that were factoring into this whole thing?

SHULKIN: Well, you know, Washington is a town that throws up all sorts of allegations. There were allegations of additional reports, but there have been no other reports that have come out. And I've addressed that.

Everything that I did on this European trip was pre-approved by Ethics, was consistent with past policies at V.A. But when the inspector-general had concerns about it, I wrote a check and I paid back every penny of a single coach airfare. That was the total amount that -- that government funds were used for, and I paid that back.

So, look, I think I've addressed that. This was used in a political way to try to remove me. And, you know, this is Washington. I'm a big -- I'm a big boy. I understand that. I've said that it shouldn't be this hard to serve your country. And I don't think it should be. But thankfully, there are many people that are still trying to fix our systems like the V.A.

BAIER: So if you had a message for the incoming secretary, should he get confirmed, what would it be?

SHULKIN: I (ph) would (ph) take to -- you know, make sure that he is consistent with the president's agenda, to push really hard, always, to keep the veterans' interests at heart. To make sure that he's working closely with congress in a bipartisan way. V.A. cannot afford to be politicized.

And make sure that he's listening to the veteran groups because, frankly, that's why we're doing this. That's what a responsive organizations needs to be successful in doing, is listening to those that have served. So I will help Dr. Jackson in any way that he needs help because it's very important that we succeed at this mission.

BAIER: Mr. Secretary, thank you for your service. Not an easy interview on this day. We appreciate your time.

SHULKIN: Thank you, Bret.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's not lady something. We know what her name is. And it is inappropriate and frankly sexist to speak in those terms. And I'm not having it in this chamber. No matter how senior a member, that parlance is not legitimate. It will not be allowed.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Secretary Johnson did eventually apologize unreservedly for what he called his inadvertent sexism. Not having it in that chamber.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for this SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and unafraid. "The Story" with guest host Sandra Smith starts right now. Sandra?

urn:contentItem:5S17-58V1-JBHT-D15F-00000-00Cyber Attack Paralyzes Part of Atlanta's Tech Infrastructure; Effect of Excessive Computer Use on Children Examined; Interview with Former Indiana Governor Mitch Daniels; President Trump Proposes Infrastructure Bill; President Trump Criticizes Amazon.2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:23ZLexisNexisCyber Attack Paralyzes Part of Atlanta's Tech Infrastructure; Effect of Excessive Computer Use on Children Examined; Interview with Former Indiana Governor Mitch Daniels; President Trump Proposes Infrastructure Bill; President Trump Criticizes Amazon.LanhamFULL TEXT

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST: Hey, Dana. Thanks.

The outgoing Veterans' Affairs secretary blasts his Washington critics, who he says cost him his job. We'll talk live with Dr. David Shulkin.

President Trump goes after Amazon again, and pushed his public-private partnership to fix America's crumbling infrastructure.

And is your child suffering from the high-tech disorder of too much screen time? Our "Kids and Culture" series continues. This is SPECIAL REPORT.

Good evening, I'm Bret Baier. Just-fired Veterans Affairs Secretary, David Shulkin, is not going quietly tonight. The latest Trump administration to be shown the door is going public with his many grievances. We'll talk with him live in just a moment.

But first, Lucas Tomlinson at the Pentagon on Shulkin's parting shots against the Washington political culture.

Good evening, Lucas.

LUCAS TOMLINSON, FOX CORRESPONDENT: Bret, President Trump used an event in Ohio today to defend the firing of his Veterans Affairs secretary, Dr. David Shulkin.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I wasn't happy with the speed with which our veterans were taken care of. We made changes because we want them taken care of. We want them to have choice so that they can run to a private doctor.

TOMLINSON (voice-over): Shulkin wasn't too happy about getting axed, and took out his frustrations in a blistering op-ed this morning.

Saying, quote, "Washington has turned so toxic, chaotic, disrespectful and subversive that it became impossible for me to accomplish the important work that our veterans need." The former secretary blamed critics for making false accusations against him. "They saw me as an obstacle to privatization."

Calls for the Obama holdover's removal boiled over following an ethics scandal, but Shulkin was quick to point out his successes: expanding access to health care, reducing wait times and working closer with the private sector.

Shulkin says the percentage of veterans who regained trust in the V.A. has risen from 46 percent four years ago to 70 percent today. Still, he struggled to win over Congress and even vets.

SEN. JERRY MORAN (R), KAN.: You led me to believe that you and I were on the same page. Our inability to reach an agreement is in significant part related to your ability to speak out of both sides of your mouth, double- talk.

TOMLINSON (voice-over): Sarah Verardo's (ph) husband has had more than 100 surgeries since being wounded in Afghanistan. She says she's ready for change.

SARAH VERARDO (ph): We need a secretary in there who is empowering and enacting the president's plan. It's a system that needs massive and total overhaul. It's a stain on our nation, and we -- we owe these heroes so much more.

TOMLINSON (voice-over): President Trump's nominee to replace Shulkin, Rear Admiral Ronny Jackson.

ADM. RONNY JACKSON, NOMINEE, U.S. VETERANS AFFAIRS SECRETARY: Some people have, you know, just great genes (ph).

TOMLINSON (voice-over): The White House physician, best known as the doctor who delivered the briefing on President Trump's physical, is already coming under fire for his credentials.

Some question whether the Navy doctor can successfully lead the federal government's second-largest department. The oldest war veterans organization saying, quote, "Doctor JacksonOs bio does not reflect any experience working with the V.A. or with veterans, or managing any organization of this size."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TOMLINSON: On Monday, Acting V.A. Secretary Robert Wilkie takes over on an interim basis. It could be months before Jackson is confirmed -- Bret.

BAIER: Lucas, thank you.

Let's hear directly, now, from Dr. Shulkin. He joins us.

Mr. Secretary, thanks for being here.

DR. DAVID SHULKIN, FORMER U.S. VETERANS AFFAIRS SECRETARY: Glad to be here, Bret.

BAIER: So let's start with this. Why do you think you were fired?

SHULKIN: Well, every cabinet member serves at the pleasure of the president, and it's the president's prerogative to have a team around him that he thinks is doing the job. I think we heard today, from the president, that he wasn't happy with the pace.

And, you know, I agree with the president. This is an organization that needs to change. It needs to do better at its job, and we all want to do it faster and better because it's so important to the country. And I -- I think the president has the right to have the secretary that he wants with him.

BAIER: You said the administration wants to privatize the V.A. Have you ever seen -- we -- we haven't seen evidence of, as far as White House policy directives sent to Congress saying that, is there any direct communication with Congress that the administration wants to privatize the V.A.?

SHULKIN: No, Bret. I actually haven't said that. I'm -- I was part of the administration until yesterday. We are not trying to privatize the V.A. We are trying to improve and transform the V.A.

What I said in my editorial is, is that there are a number of political appointees within V.A. that are pushing to privatize much faster than I think is in the interest of veterans and is the safe way to care for our veterans.

And I've -- I've stood up for them because I was in Washington and I was working for the president on behalf of our veterans.

BAIER: Why did you feel the need to write the op-ed?

SHULKIN: Well, listen, I think it's important. I came to Washington from the private sector for one reason, to fix the V.A. I know this matters a lot to the president. And we as a country have a long way to go to get the V.A. in -- in proper shape.

But it would be a mistake to conclude that we do not need the V.A. and that we have to dismantle the V.A. We have to improve the V.A. while at the same time working with the private sector in an integrated way to meet the needs of our veterans.

BAIER: You know, we heard this sound bite in Lucas' piece from Senator Moran, questioning your dealings with that particular committee. Did -- did you have a credibility issue with Congress?

SHULKIN: Oh, I don't think so. You have to remember, I'm the only cabinet member that had 100 to zero vote. I've prided myself in working in a bipartisan way.

Senator Moran felt strongly about pushing to give veterans additional options that, frankly, his own senators, the committee, didn't agree with. He lost his amendment 14 to one. He was the only one voting against it. And he was frustrated by that.

And, by the way, he had some reasonable points there. So there are many things that he and I agreed upon. But in the end, he didn't like the position that I took, which was to do what I thought was the right thing for our veterans.

BAIER: About 11 months ago, I had you on SPECIAL REPORT. We were talking about the challenges. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Have things changed? Are you seeing change?

SHULKIN: We're in the intensive care unit. And we're monitoring things really closely, but I am optimistic that we're beginning to finally deal with the issues that have plagued the V.A. system for decades.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: So the president said today that he just wasn't happy, how fast or how -- how things were going. That they were going too slowly. What's your response to that, and what can be done to -- to change that pace?

SHULKIN: Well, I don't think the president should be happy with where we were. And as secretary, I wasn't happy with where we were. We have to figure out how to move this bureaucracy faster and be more responsive.

When you showed the Verardos, I know Michael and Sarah very well. And frankly, this was a system that failed them and we shouldn't be doing that. So -- so this is a system that needs to be pushed. Many of the bureaucratic elements need to be restructured. I've started that process. I hope that Dr. Jackson will continue that process because it needs to be done.

BAIER: You know, you had the inspector-general, obviously, come out with this scathing report about -- about your trip to Europe. We -- we've been over that and your response to that. Were there other I.G. investigations or audits that -- that were factoring into this whole thing?

SHULKIN: Well, you know, Washington is a town that throws up all sorts of allegations. There were allegations of additional reports, but there have been no other reports that have come out. And I've addressed that.

Everything that I did on this European trip was pre-approved by Ethics, was consistent with past policies at V.A. But when the inspector-general had concerns about it, I wrote a check and I paid back every penny of a single coach airfare. That was the total amount that -- that government funds were used for, and I paid that back.

So, look, I think I've addressed that. This was used in a political way to try to remove me. And, you know, this is Washington. I'm a big -- I'm a big boy. I understand that. I've said that it shouldn't be this hard to serve your country. And I don't think it should be. But thankfully, there are many people that are still trying to fix our systems like the V.A.

BAIER: So if you had a message for the incoming secretary, should he get confirmed, what would it be?

SHULKIN: I (ph) would (ph) take to -- you know, make sure that he is consistent with the president's agenda, to push really hard, always, to keep the veterans' interests at heart. To make sure that he's working closely with congress in a bipartisan way. V.A. cannot afford to be politicized.

And make sure that he's listening to the veteran groups because, frankly, that's why we're doing this. That's what a responsive organizations needs to be successful in doing, is listening to those that have served. So I will help Dr. Jackson in any way that he needs help because it's very important that we succeed at this mission.

BAIER: Mr. Secretary, thank you for your service. Not an easy interview on this day. We appreciate your time.

SHULKIN: Thank you, Bret.

BAIER: This is a FOX NEWS alert. The attorney general says there will be no second special counsel for now. Jeff Sessions is rejecting a Republican request for a special prosecutor to look into alleged bias at the Justice Department and the FBI.

But he is authorizing an investigation, and leaving the door open for more possible action later. Chief national correspondent Ed Henry is here with the breaking details.

Good evening, Ed.

ED HENRY, FOX CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Bret. This could be a big deal. Because what the attorney general is really saying is, he may not need a second special counsel just yet to find out whether FBI and Justice Department officials during the Obama years broke laws when they engaged in FISA abuse to spy on the Trump campaign because he already has a criminal prosecutor all over it.

Sessions revealing for the first time, he already has been quietly having U.S. attorney John Huber of Utah operating, of course, outside of the beltway, using his prosecutorial powers with a broad mandate to investigate misconduct that could extend beyond FISA abuse.

So former FBI officials James Comey, Andrew McCabe could be facing scrutiny for not just failing to tell the FISA judge that the anti-Trump dossier was paid for by the DNC and the Clinton campaign. This prosecutor could be looking at McCabe's leaking, his lying to investigators, plus those FBI text messages.

Sessions writing, quote, "I am confident, Mr. Huber's review will include a full, complete and objective evaluation of these matters in a manner that is consistent with the law and the facts. I receive regular updates from Mr. Huber and upon the conclusion of his review, will receive his recommendations as to whether any matters not currently under investigation should be opened, whether any matters currently under investigation require further resources or whether any matters merit the appointment of a special counsel."

Now, Sessions faced heat again last night when it was revealed, the Justice Department inspector-general was reviewing this, and critics said that -- that official there does not have prosecutorial powers.

Well, John Huber does. And remember, Sessions hinted this without naming Humer -- Huber in a recent interview with Shannon Bream. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEFF SESSIONS, U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: I have appointed a person outside of Washington, many years in the Department of Justice, to look at all the allegations that the House Judiciary Committee members sent to us, and we're conducting that investigation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: Now Huber was first nominated by then-President Barack Obama, so if he brings criminal charges it will have credibility. Likewise, if he finds no criminal wrongdoing it will be noted, this was someone who was re- nominated by President Trump with the backing, we should note, of conservative Republican Utah senator, Mike Lee -- Bret.

BAIER: All right. We'll follow this one, Ed. Thank you.

U.S. officials say there is no justification for Russia's retaliatory moves to expel 60 American diplomats and shutter the U.S. consulate in St. Petersburg.

Russia's foreign minister announced the action today. It's the Kremlin's response to punitive measures over its alleged involvement in the poisoning of a Russian -- a former Russian spy in England. Also today, we learned the deceased spy's daughter, who was also affected in that attack, is no longer in critical condition.

While not deceased, the other attack -- while we were probably active today -- you may have been on Amazon, who knows, this afternoon, for any number of items. President Trump was going hard after the online giant for what he says is behavior that is bad for America.

The president is also making a strong push for his infrastructure rejuvenization -- rejuvenation plan, which is "necessary for America," he says. Correspondent Kevin Corke is at the White House tonight with that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Anything we can dream, you can build. You will create the new highways, the new dams and skyscrapers that will become lasting monuments to American strength and continued greatness.

KEVIN CORKE, FOX WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Back on the road, and looking to get the White House back on message.

TRUMP: We're now finally putting America first. America first.

(APPLAUSE)

CORKE (voice-over): President Trump traveled to Ohio today, to unveil his administration's infrastructure plan to use $200 billion in federal money to spur at least a trillion and a half in spending over a decade to repair or replace highways, bridges, ports and airports.

TRUMP: We'll transform our roads and bridges from a source of endless frustration into a source of absolutely incredible pride.

CORKE (voice-over): The appearance, his first in public in nearly a week, comes amid reports that, once again, he is prepared to take aim at a business behemoth: Amazon and its CEO, Jeff Bezos, who also owns the "Washington Post," which the president has criticized for being unfair to his administration.

In fact, he's criticized Bezos and Amazon on Twitter more than a dozen times since late 2015, including today. This time, accusing the online retailer of paying little or no taxes, using the postal system as their delivery boy, and putting retailers out of business.

While Amazon does pay taxes -- about $412 million in 2016, according to SEC filings -- some municipalities complain the company doesn't collect enough local taxes or taxes on goods sold by third parties on its platform.

RAJ SHAH, WHITE HOUSE PRINCIPAL DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: This is really about policy. You have a huge company that's done amazing things, and Amazon sprang (ph) up in a very short amount of time. And, really, tax policy and other policy has to catch up to that so that way -- those who are competing with Amazon are on a level playing field.

CORKE (voice-over): The White House has declined to confirm if any new policies or actions are in the works. But the president has talked openly about the possibility of a change to Amazon's tax status through anti-trust rules, much to the dismay of some analysts.

JOHN LAYFIELD, FINANCIAL ANALYST: This is not standard oil, this is not the telephone company. They have about 5 percent of retail sales right now. That is hardly a monopoly at all.

CORKE (voice-over): Despite the president's tweet, the online retailer is thought by many to actually be helping to keep the postal service viable by driving up package delivery revenue at a time when first-class mail volume continues to drop.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CORKE: Bret, talking about the U.S. postal service, there, you may find this interesting. Its board of governors last had a member in December of 2016. No one's been replaced since that point. In fact, it now sits empty for the first time since its creation all the way back in 1970. More work to do for the Trump administration -- Bret.

BAIER: Kevin Corke, out (ph) on the North Lawn.

Kevin, thank you.

Stocks closed out a volatile week and month. On the positive side, the Dow gained 255 today. The S&P 500 finished ahead 36. The NASDAQ picked up 114. What a big difference a day makes. Let's get some additional information tonight about tech stocks and the markets.

Deirdre Bolton of FOX BUSINESS NETWORK joins us, as she does, from New York.

Good evening, Deirdre.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX ANCHOR: Good evening, Bret. So investors bought some of the tech stocks that have fallen so much in the past few sessions: Facebook, Apple, Netflix, Alphabet, Google, Microsoft all closed higher.

Still a lot of long-term concerns about tech, though, with specific companies facing potential regulation. So Facebook, one example of that. It announced a few quick fixes today, presumably before Mark Zuckerberg testifies in front of Congress on April 10th.

So Facebook made its privacy controls easier to find (ph), easier to alter. It also cut off certain customer-targeting companies from the platform.

Tech companies face potential government challenges, investor pressure and public peer review. Apple CEO, Tim Cook, took a swipe at Facebook at a conference, saying, "The best regulation is no regulation" -- self- regulation -- "however, I think we're way beyond that here." Facebook's stock did close higher today, but it is down about 10 percent for the month.

Apple, speaking of Tim Cook, faces more than a dozen class-action lawsuits. Consumer groups charge that it intentionally slowed older iPhones or failed to disclose power use changes with updated operating systems, so consumer groups say it was meant to encourage people to buy new, upgraded, more expensive phones.

President Trump put Amazon in the crosshairs again, in a response to a tweet. Analysts say Amazon has not broken any tax laws, and reports show that the U.S. postal service suffers from high labor costs and from paying into federal workers' pension and health care plans, not from delivering packages for Amazon.

Bigger picture? Tech has grown so far, so fast. It has an outsized influence on the stock market. And today is a really great example. So when tech rallied, overall markets rallied. But strategists say it is difficult to see what other groups of stocks will take over market leadership if tech falters -- Bret, back to you.

BAIER: Deirdre, thank you.

A California judge has ruled Starbucks and other coffee sellers must include cancer warnings on coffees sold in the state of California.

The judge says the companies have failed to show the threat from a chemical compound, produced in the coffee-roasting process, is insignificant. The coffee industry says the chemical is present -- present at harmless levels, and should be exempt from the law because it results naturally from the cooking process.

Up next, an emotional funeral for an African-American man shot by police who thought he had a gun. Plus, your kids and screen time: What do you need to know?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: A funeral was held today for an unarmed African-American man, shot by police who thought the cell phone in his hand was a gun. The March 18th incident has sparked days of unrest in Sacramento. Correspondent Claudia Cowan is live right now in the California capital.

Good evening, Claudia.

CLAUDIA COWAN, FOX CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Bret. Well as they have all week, protestors with Black Lives Matter and other community groups have camped out here, at the Sacramento County district attorney's office.

They are demanding that prosecutors file criminal charges against the two officers involved in the fatal shooting of Stephon Clark. They also want to see sweeping changes in police departments across the country.

Clark, a 22-year-old father of two boys, was laid to rest today. His funeral drew hundreds of mourners as well as prominent Civil Rights activists. As he supported Clark's grieving brother, Reverend Al Sharpton gave the eulogy and called out the Trump administration.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REV. AL SHARPTON: Yesterday, the president's press secretary said, "This is a local matter." No, this is not a local matter. They've been killing young black men all over the country. And we are here to say that we're going to stand with Stephon Clark --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

COWAN (voice-over): Video of the nighttime shooting has sparked controversy. Officers were chasing a robbery suspect, and thought Clark had a gun. It turned out to be a cell phone.

And then right after the shooting, officers were told to mute their body cameras. And demonstrators are demanding an explanation for why the audio was cut. Police will only say that is part of the ongoing investigation.

In the meantime, city leaders are hoping to resume what they're calling a community dialogue next week, so that residents can vent their anger and offer solutions. The meeting this past Tuesday night turned chaotic when Clark's brother Stevante highjacked the mike and jumped on the dais.

He has since apologized, and is asking the protestors not to interfere with tonight's Sacramento Kings basketball game. At two of the last three home games, police stood by while activists blocked the doors and the arena was locked down. The Kings organization is assuring ticketholders that they will have safe access to tonight's game.

A protest in support of police is now scheduled for this weekend, and those two officers involved in Stephon Clark's shooting remain on paid administrative leave -- Bret.

BAIER: Claudia Cowan, live in Sacramento.

Claudia, thank you.

Back in Washington, Defense Secretary James Mattis met today with incoming National Security Advisor John Bolton. The former U.N. ambassador will replace Lieutenant-General H.R. McMaster.

The Pentagon chief kept things light at the beginning.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES MATTIS, U.S. SECRETARY OF DEFENSE: Good to finally meet you.

JOHN BOLTON, U.S. NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR: Absolutely.

MATTIS: I've heard that you're actually the devil incarnate, and I wanted to meet you.

(LAUGHTER)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Heard you're the devil incarnate, some of Bolton's conservative views, obviously, have drawn the ire of the Left.

Up next, a major American city still has not recovered from a massive cyber-attack.

First, beyond our borders tonight, the families of 68 people killed in a fire at a Venezuelan police station jail are demanding information and answers tonight. The fast-moving blaze tore through the facility in Valencia, about 100 miles from the capital, Caracas. Venezuelan jails are overcrowded and inmates often go hungry, as the nation struggles through a massive economic crisis.

Italian police have arrested five people connected to the Tunisian terrorist responsible for the Berlin Christmas market truck attack in 2016. Anis Amri killed 12 people and died in a shootout with police four days later.

And former French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, is being ordered to stand trial on corruption and influence-peddling charges. It's one of several corruption investigations targeting Sarkozy. It is the second scheduled for trial. Sarkozy denied all wrongdoing.

Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: The city of Atlanta is still in recovery mode tonight, after a massive cyber-attack crippled many computers and systems over the past week. And the situation is still far from resolved.

Correspondent Jonathan Serrie shows us from Atlanta.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEISHA LANCE BOTTOMS, MAYOR OF ATLANTA: This is a marathon, not a sprint.

JONATHAN SERRIE, FOX CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): A week after a ransomware cyberattack paralyzed Atlanta's computer system, the city is still unable to process payments for water bills and traffic tickets. Municipal court hearings set for today are being rescheduled, and some city services are returning to pen and paper.

BOTTOMS: It was a sustainable model until we got computer systems. So it worked for many years. And for some of our younger employees, it will be a nice exercise in good penmanship.

(LAUGHTER)

SERRIE: But it's not a laughing matter. Atlanta officials haven't decided if they should pay the cyber criminals the $51,000 ransom to unlock their files or manually restore each desktop and laptop connected to the city's network which is quite a lengthy process.

ANDREW GREEN, KENNESAW STATE UNIVERSITY: They're in a no win situation. They're going to end up choosing what is the most -- the least painful of all bad solutions. There is no good solution to this. They're going to get criticized if they pay. They're going to get criticized if they don't pay.

SERRIE: Andrew Green, an information security lecturer with Kennesaw State University, says municipalities in general are vulnerable to cyberattack because they strive to provide 24/7 online services at minimal cost to taxpayers.

GREEN: They're expected to do all of this with a shoestring budget. And so this is a wake-up call potentially. Cities need to start looking at how seriously they're taking their own cyber security posture.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SERRIE: Atlanta officials say they don't believe anyone's personal information was compromised and the cyberattack did not affect the city's 911 system or the world's busiest airport. But as a precaution, the airport has shut down its public wi-fi system and disabled the flight information feature on its website. Bret?

BAIER: Jonathan, thank you.

Former Indiana governor and current president of Purdue University Mitch Daniels has some things to say about the use and abuse of technology and big data. He has just written an op-ed in "The Washington Post" titled "Someone is Watching You". He joins us tonight from Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana. Governor, thanks for being here. Why write this op-ed?

MITCH DANIELS, (R) FORMER INDIANA GOVERNOR: It was something of a surprise to us, Bret, here how much we knew about our students, and we're beginning to discover ways we can use it to their benefit. We want to do that. Let them know things that would be -- that correlate with academic success and they're progressing better here at Purdue.

But at the same time, we can tell there could be misuses of that sort of data, and I wrote it just because I know there are institutions of all kinds who are now in possession of information in enormous quantities and we're all going to have some questions to ask about ourselves about making sure we do the right thing, not the wrong thing with it.

BAIER: That line between privacy and what you could use with that data, obviously, is something we deal with. In this op-ed, you say people serene in their assurance that they know what is best for others, have to stop and ask themselves on what authority they became the nudgers and great approvers. Many of us will have to stop and ask whether our good intentions are carrying us past boundaries are privacy and individual autonomy should still prevail.

I mean, that is in fact, not only on college campuses but what we're dealing with with these big tech companies and what they know about all of us.

DANIELS: And in government and in many other walks of life. There are many people, and it always, of course, is motivated by what they believe are good intentions who think they know what's best for others. And armed with these mountains of new information, they will be discovering patterns that they would like to encourage others to follow, that produce what in the nudger's eye is a good result.

So this is something I think to be careful about. There's somewhere, as I say, between helping a struggling student -- identifying a struggling student and connecting them with a tutor, and really shoving people into behaviors that somebody has decided are preferable. There's a line. And we ought to be debating it in individual institutions and collectively.

BAIER: I just want to get your thoughts about a couple of things. One is we're getting ready for this testimony up on Capitol Hill. Congress with the big tech companies, Facebook, Google, testifying before Congress. And there's really consideration about regulation. Where do you think that goes?

DANIELS: Well, he always got to regulate with great, great caution and thought. But this may be an area. There are certain, certainly antitrust and the suspicion of business is not without its foundation in American history. And we have set up various boundaries beyond which we don't think institutions should grow and sprawl. And it's hard not to notice the incredible concentration in that industry. It has economic consequences and now we know it has major societal consequence when's that much information is in that few hands.

BAIER: Two more things. One is you're historically a big deficit hawk. Somebody who is concerned about the deficit and debt for a long time. You talked about it. Just been through this whole omnibus spending issue. What are your thoughts on that and where the country is heading?

DANIELS: I'm very troubled. It shouldn't escape people's notice there was a massive amount of the discussion, debate, and there should have been about a tax bill that may over 10 years increase the deficit by $1 trillion. Not to be sneezed at, but when you're already at $20 trillion, it's only the percentage that it is.

Right on its heels, Congress happily and cheerfully passed a $2 trillion addition to spending. We finally found something people there can get together on and compromise on, but it was probably the wrong thing. And the looming debt that we have built is an economic menace, the biggest one to this country in the opinion of many of us. And to our future prosperity, it's also -- without question, a moral dubious thing to dump on the next generation, bills not for money that was borrowed and invested in their future but for many that their elders borrowed and spent on themselves. And the problem here, Bret, is I keep telling people, the can is getting heavier, and we're running out of road.

BAIER: And quickly, this weekend is the NCAA final four. Condoleezza Rice has been asked to head up a committee looking at the NCAA basketball and some of the problems they've been having. You've written about that as well. Your thoughts as we head into this weekend?

DANIELS: It's a little like the big data column. I'm all questions and very few answers. The one thing I know and think is very hard to argue with is the status quo in Division One basketball needs a lot of repair. We've seen corruption. We've seen the game, in essence, semi- professionalized, although the people, the young men who are creating all the value don't get paid for it. And something really needs to change.

I'm so glad that the NCAA has acted and commissioned a group led by someone like Condi Rice with her tremendous judgment and credibility. And there's some other good people on there. In the column, I threw out three ideas but they're probably the wrong ideas. I don't pretend to know the exact answer, but we need to reinstate the era, really, of genuine student athletes. And those who are really only attending college to pursue an athletic career and pretending to be students with the complicity of the institutions ought to be paid above the table in some sort of minor league, in my opinion.

Looking forward to a great tournament. There are four great teams there this weekend. All credit to them. But the system as a whole should not go on as it is much longer.

BAIER: Governor Daniels, we appreciate your time tonight.

DANIELS: Thanks for having me.

BAIER: When we come back, are your kids misbehaving because you let them spend too much time looking at a screen?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Tonight, we continue our series on kids and culture with a look at how much is too much high-tech, and how it can be a very bad thing for your children. They even have a fancy name for it now. Correspondent Ellison Barber tells us what this is, what it means, and what can be done.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ELLISON BARBER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: All parents want what's best for their kids. They want them to be healthy, happy. But what if small thing --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Just football and Minecraft.

BARBER: -- threaten that.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's very worrisome because it's so part of our lives.

BARBER: Dana is a mom of three.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: A 14-year-old, an 11-year-old and an eight-year-old.

BARBER: And they, like so many of us, enjoy technology, Especially her youngest.

If somebody took it away in the middle of the game, would you be a little bit mad? Or not really?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'd be a little bit mad because I'm like doing -- it's like really hard work and so it takes it away and you're almost finished with that thing.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: That's happened before. He'll be in the middle of building something and I yank it away from him because I can't get his attention.

BARBER: What do you do when that happens?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I don't want to get into that.

BARBER: Dr. Victoria Dunckley says with a lot of children, their nervous systems are being overstimulated by electronics, and her research shows it leads to behavioral problems.

DR. VICTORIA DUNCKLEY, RESET YOUR CHILD'S BRAIN: The vivid colors and the rapid pace, all that is hard for the brain to process.

BARBER: It's a phenomenon she calls electronic screen time syndrome.

DUNCKLEY: Lot of kids become very irritable or they're tearful or some kids actually have full blown rages. Other kids are anxious. And a lot of kids will have trouble following directions.

BARBER: A 2010 study found that every day, eight to 18-year-olds spend an average of seven hours and 38 minutes using entertainment media. But some say technology isn't the issue. Parents can help their kids to use it in beneficial ways.

SARA DEWITT, PBS KIDS DIGITAL: They can help introduce kids to new things in the world, places they have never seen before. They can help them play with ideas in a way that it's harder to her do sometimes just like with a paper and pencil.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I used to have trouble reading. So I used to do this website. It helps you read like different books.

BARBER: Dunkley says the effects of too much screen time are sometimes misdiagnosed as behavioral and mental health disorders. If you're worried about your child, she recommends a detox.

DUNCKLEY: It allows the brain to get deep rest so the stress hormones normalize.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARBER: And as kids become teens, the digital barrage only intensifies in the form of smartphones. According to Pew Research Center, 73 percent of American teens have a smartphone, 92 percent say they go online daily. Researchers say that percentage is fueled by smartphones. Bret?

BAIER: Ellison, thank you. Last part of the series tomorrow. We can all use a little digital time-out every now and then.

The Vatican is disputing an interpretation of comments by Pope Francis that have the pontiff declaring there is no Hell. It says the story during this holy week in an Italian newspaper is a reconstruction that does not contain direct quotes from the Pope. The story purports to quote the pontiff as saying Hell does not exist and condemned souls just disappear. The writer has a history of interpretation conflicts with the Vatican.

Next up, infrastructure, the tech industry, and your privacy -- the panel joins me after a quick break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Now, finally, putting America first. First, we'll invest in the American worker.

We will breathe new life into your very rundown highways, railways, and waterways. We'll transform our roads and bridges from a source of endless frustration into a source of absolutely incredible pride.

I've asked Republicans and Democrats in Congress to come together and deliver the biggest and boldest infrastructure plan in the last half century. The plan generates an unprecedented $1.5 trillion investment in American infrastructure.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: The president in Ohio with this plan on infrastructure, kind of laying that out in a very campaign style speech for President Trump. The bullet points here, $200 billion in federal funding to spur, as he mentioned, $1.5 trillion in infrastructure investments, kind of a public/private partnership, $100 billion for incentives program for additional investments, states, localities, private sector, $50 billion rebuilding rural infrastructure, $20 billion promoting infrastructure projects, $20 billion expanding the financing programs, $10 billion in capital revolving fund to help reduce inefficient federal property leasing.

What about this? Let's bring in our panel. Katie Pavlich, news editor at Townhall.com, Susan Page, Washington bureau chief at "USA Today," and Bill McGurn, Main Street columnist for the "Wall Street Journal." Bill, realistic?

WILLIAM MCGURN, MAIN STREET, COLUMNIST, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": It's a little realistic. Look, the problem isn't can we build this stuff? There's two problems. Who is going to pay for it? And can we get permission to build it from the regulatory process? So those are the areas I think where the president could have a little morning impact. We need a reform of how it's done.

In New York and New Jersey, for example, so much of this should have been done by the local and state governments. But because of the spending problems that they have, they don't have the money for it.

BAIER: Susan?

SUSAN PAGE, WASHINGTON BUREAU CHIEF, "USA TODAY": I think there are some cities and states who see this as not a realistic prospect because it requires them to come up with so much of the money. There's traditionally been an 80/20 federal, state split. This puts it the other way around, the federal government putting 20 percent of the infrastructure spending.

Now, that's said, I think there is a bipartisan, across the country consensus that we need to have a bigger investment in infrastructure. But I'm not sure the president's plan is one that is politically feasible, and I think the prospects that it gets through Congress this year are pretty slim.

BAIER: Speaking of process, we just went through this omnibus, and I just talked to Governor Daniels about that. It doesn't seem like big legislative things are going to happen prior to the midterms. Do you agree with that, Katie?

KATIE PAVLICH, NEWS EDITOR, TOWNHALL.COM: Well, according to a White House senior official today, they're not looking for this to be a big infrastructure plan in terms of it being one big piece of legislation. They actually want to move this in parts. They want certain committees on Capitol Hill to take a look at the details and push them through individually. So I do think that there is a chance that some of these things can get past in bites and pieces rather than in a bigger piece of legislation.

But I want to go back quickly to the states issue. Yes, the states are going to have to take on a lot of responsibility here. But you can argue because of that, there will be more accountability in terms of the types of projects that they do and that they have to take a look at things they actually need rather than going back to the stimulus type package that we had with little accountability and all of the federal government money just getting dumped in for the sake of doing projects. States are going to have to take a look at what they actually need and make sure the money they are putting on the table and the money they're getting from the federal government is well spent to better their infrastructure in their states.

BAIER: Clearly, Bill, there is a process that is tough to go through if you're trying to do any big project in any state, that the hoops that you have to go through, that's what they're trying to affect.

MCGURN: Yes, but back to Katie's point, I think it's a good point. You know, if the federal government is going to pick up most of the tab, there's not a lot of incentive for states to be careful about the money being spent. In New York, of course, we have this issue with the Gateway project, the new tunnel and, you know, nine out of 10 people who would use that are people like me, local commuters. And so I would think, why should someone in Mississippi have to pay for that, or have to pay for the bulk of that?

So I think we need -- what would be nice is a lot of reform that creates incentives for states to focus on what they really need and start to pay for it themselves.

BAIER: Donald Trump, the president today, had one company in his sights. He tweeted out "I have stated my concerns with Amazon long before the election. Unlike others, they pay little or no taxes to state and local governments, use our postal system as their delivery boy, causing tremendous loss to the U.S., and are putting many thousands of retailers out of business." Susan, it seems like he has Amazon, perhaps, in his sights.

PAGE: He does, and there may be a variety of reasons why. He's criticized Amazon before, and linked Jeff Bezos who owns Amazon with "The Washington Post" which he also owns. And that -- some people think that's part of his motivation for taking on Amazon.

It is true that Amazon has been disruptive for a lot of small businesses in communities, and that's a fair conversation to have. It is not accurate to say that Amazon does not collect sales tax, however. Since last April, April of 2017, so for the last year, Amazon has had a policy of collecting sales tax wherever there are communities -- states where sales tax is levied. So that's a criticism that used to be made against Amazon that I think is now a little out of date.

BAIER: Here's Steve Forbes asked about this kind of focusing in on one company, a big company, Amazon.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVE FORBES, FORBES MEDIA CHAIRMAN: Free markets will work in bringing that company down just as it does with any other company over time. I'm old enough to remember G.M. when that was the big, bad company, IBM when that was the big, bad company.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And Microsoft.

FORBES: Wal-Mart was going to take over the world. Now it's struggling. So let the free markets play out.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Katie?

PAVLICH: Yes, I understand the president's willingness and urge to level the playing field certainly. But if he's going after Jeff Bezos and Amazon for personal reasons, then it's certainly an abuse of power. Look, states have taken this on themselves in terms of looking at the way that Amazon does third party sales and implemented their own types of sales tax. So I also believe that the free market will come into play here.

The other thing, too, is there is Supreme Court precedence for this going back to the 1990s when catalogs were selling goods from state to state and sales tax was not being paid in states that they were not actually located. And the Supreme Court ruled in favor of the catalog. Amazon is a little bit different and the Supreme Court will hear a case in April dealing with the tech side of that. But we have seen that this is not just an Amazon issue. There is some legal precedent here about the taxes and the way that they work when you're selling from a third party or from a different state.

BAIER: Lot of states and cities are courting Amazon for a big building somewhere. We'll see where that goes. Panel, as always, thank you.

When we come back, the lady doth protest, and so did her colleagues.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Finally tonight, that's no way to treat a lady.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Whatever it is. I can't remember what it is. Isn't that extraordinary?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson hit a nerve Tuesday when he addressed parliament member Emily Thornberry by her spouse's title rather than her preferred maiden name, then this happened.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's not lady something. We know what her name is. And it is inappropriate and frankly sexist to speak in those terms. And I'm not having it in this chamber. No matter how senior a member, that parlance is not legitimate. It will not be allowed.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Secretary Johnson did eventually apologize unreservedly for what he called his inadvertent sexism. Not having it in that chamber.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for this SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and unafraid. "The Story" with guest host Sandra Smith starts right now. Sandra?

END

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST: Hey, Dana. Thanks.

The outgoing Veterans' Affairs secretary blasts his Washington critics, who he says cost him his job. We'll talk live with Dr. David Shulkin.

President Trump goes after Amazon again, and pushed his public-private partnership to fix America's crumbling infrastructure.

And is your child suffering from the high-tech disorder of too much screen time? Our "Kids and Culture" series continues. This is SPECIAL REPORT.

Good evening, I'm Bret Baier. Just-fired Veterans Affairs Secretary, David Shulkin, is not going quietly tonight. The latest Trump administration to be shown the door is going public with his many grievances. We'll talk with him live in just a moment.

But first, Lucas Tomlinson at the Pentagon on Shulkin's parting shots against the Washington political culture.

Good evening, Lucas.

LUCAS TOMLINSON, FOX CORRESPONDENT: Bret, President Trump used an event in Ohio today to defend the firing of his Veterans Affairs secretary, Dr. David Shulkin.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I wasn't happy with the speed with which our veterans were taken care of. We made changes because we want them taken care of. We want them to have choice so that they can run to a private doctor.

TOMLINSON (voice-over): Shulkin wasn't too happy about getting axed, and took out his frustrations in a blistering op-ed this morning.

Saying, quote, "Washington has turned so toxic, chaotic, disrespectful and subversive that it became impossible for me to accomplish the important work that our veterans need." The former secretary blamed critics for making false accusations against him. "They saw me as an obstacle to privatization."

Calls for the Obama holdover's removal boiled over following an ethics scandal, but Shulkin was quick to point out his successes: expanding access to health care, reducing wait times and working closer with the private sector.

Shulkin says the percentage of veterans who regained trust in the V.A. has risen from 46 percent four years ago to 70 percent today. Still, he struggled to win over Congress and even vets.

SEN. JERRY MORAN (R), KAN.: You led me to believe that you and I were on the same page. Our inability to reach an agreement is in significant part related to your ability to speak out of both sides of your mouth, double- talk.

TOMLINSON (voice-over): Sarah Verardo's (ph) husband has had more than 100 surgeries since being wounded in Afghanistan. She says she's ready for change.

SARAH VERARDO (ph): We need a secretary in there who is empowering and enacting the president's plan. It's a system that needs massive and total overhaul. It's a stain on our nation, and we -- we owe these heroes so much more.

TOMLINSON (voice-over): President Trump's nominee to replace Shulkin, Rear Admiral Ronny Jackson.

ADM. RONNY JACKSON, NOMINEE, U.S. VETERANS AFFAIRS SECRETARY: Some people have, you know, just great genes (ph).

TOMLINSON (voice-over): The White House physician, best known as the doctor who delivered the briefing on President Trump's physical, is already coming under fire for his credentials.

Some question whether the Navy doctor can successfully lead the federal government's second-largest department. The oldest war veterans organization saying, quote, "Doctor JacksonOs bio does not reflect any experience working with the V.A. or with veterans, or managing any organization of this size."

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TOMLINSON: On Monday, Acting V.A. Secretary Robert Wilkie takes over on an interim basis. It could be months before Jackson is confirmed -- Bret.

BAIER: Lucas, thank you.

Let's hear directly, now, from Dr. Shulkin. He joins us.

Mr. Secretary, thanks for being here.

DR. DAVID SHULKIN, FORMER U.S. VETERANS AFFAIRS SECRETARY: Glad to be here, Bret.

BAIER: So let's start with this. Why do you think you were fired?

SHULKIN: Well, every cabinet member serves at the pleasure of the president, and it's the president's prerogative to have a team around him that he thinks is doing the job. I think we heard today, from the president, that he wasn't happy with the pace.

And, you know, I agree with the president. This is an organization that needs to change. It needs to do better at its job, and we all want to do it faster and better because it's so important to the country. And I -- I think the president has the right to have the secretary that he wants with him.

BAIER: You said the administration wants to privatize the V.A. Have you ever seen -- we -- we haven't seen evidence of, as far as White House policy directives sent to Congress saying that, is there any direct communication with Congress that the administration wants to privatize the V.A.?

SHULKIN: No, Bret. I actually haven't said that. I'm -- I was part of the administration until yesterday. We are not trying to privatize the V.A. We are trying to improve and transform the V.A.

What I said in my editorial is, is that there are a number of political appointees within V.A. that are pushing to privatize much faster than I think is in the interest of veterans and is the safe way to care for our veterans.

And I've -- I've stood up for them because I was in Washington and I was working for the president on behalf of our veterans.

BAIER: Why did you feel the need to write the op-ed?

SHULKIN: Well, listen, I think it's important. I came to Washington from the private sector for one reason, to fix the V.A. I know this matters a lot to the president. And we as a country have a long way to go to get the V.A. in -- in proper shape.

But it would be a mistake to conclude that we do not need the V.A. and that we have to dismantle the V.A. We have to improve the V.A. while at the same time working with the private sector in an integrated way to meet the needs of our veterans.

BAIER: You know, we heard this sound bite in Lucas' piece from Senator Moran, questioning your dealings with that particular committee. Did -- did you have a credibility issue with Congress?

SHULKIN: Oh, I don't think so. You have to remember, I'm the only cabinet member that had 100 to zero vote. I've prided myself in working in a bipartisan way.

Senator Moran felt strongly about pushing to give veterans additional options that, frankly, his own senators, the committee, didn't agree with. He lost his amendment 14 to one. He was the only one voting against it. And he was frustrated by that.

And, by the way, he had some reasonable points there. So there are many things that he and I agreed upon. But in the end, he didn't like the position that I took, which was to do what I thought was the right thing for our veterans.

BAIER: About 11 months ago, I had you on SPECIAL REPORT. We were talking about the challenges. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Have things changed? Are you seeing change?

Unlike others, they pay little or no taxes to state and local governments, use our postal system as their delivery boy, causing tremendous loss to the U.S., and are putting many thousands of retailers out of business." Susan, it seems like he has Amazon, perhaps, in his sights.

PAGE: He does, and there may be a variety of reasons why. He's criticized Amazon before, and linked Jeff Bezos who owns Amazon with "The Washington Post" which he also owns. And that -- some people think that's part of his motivation for taking on Amazon.

It is true that Amazon has been disruptive for a lot of small businesses in communities, and that's a fair conversation to have. It is not accurate to say that Amazon does not collect sales tax, however. Since last April, April of 2017, so for the last year, Amazon has had a policy of collecting sales tax wherever there are communities -- states where sales tax is levied. So that's a criticism that used to be made against Amazon that I think is now a little out of date.

BAIER: Here's Steve Forbes asked about this kind of focusing in on one company, a big company, Amazon.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVE FORBES, FORBES MEDIA CHAIRMAN: Free markets will work in bringing that company down just as it does with any other company over time. I'm old enough to remember G.M. when that was the big, bad company, IBM when that was the big, bad company.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And Microsoft.

FORBES: Wal-Mart was going to take over the world. Now it's struggling. So let the free markets play out.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Katie?

PAVLICH: Yes, I understand the president's willingness and urge to level the playing field certainly. But if he's going after Jeff Bezos and Amazon for personal reasons, then it's certainly an abuse of power. Look, states have taken this on themselves in terms of looking at the way that Amazon does third party sales and implemented their own types of sales tax. So I also believe that the free market will come into play here.

The other thing, too, is there is Supreme Court precedence for this going back to the 1990s when catalogs were selling goods from state to state and sales tax was not being paid in states that they were not actually located. And the Supreme Court ruled in favor of the catalog. Amazon is a little bit different and the Supreme Court will hear a case in April dealing with the tech side of that. But we have seen that this is not just an Amazon issue. There is some legal precedent here about the taxes and the way that they work when you're selling from a third party or from a different state.

BAIER: Lot of states and cities are courting Amazon for a big building somewhere. We'll see where that goes. Panel, as always, thank you.

When we come back, the lady doth protest, and so did her colleagues.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Finally tonight, that's no way to treat a lady.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Whatever it is. I can't remember what it is. Isn't that extraordinary?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson hit a nerve Tuesday when he addressed parliament member Emily Thornberry by her spouse's title rather than her preferred maiden name, then this happened.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's not lady something. We know what her name is. And it is inappropriate and frankly sexist to speak in those terms. And I'm not having it in this chamber. No matter how senior a member, that parlance is not legitimate. It will not be allowed.

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Secretary Johnson did eventually apologize unreservedly for what he called his inadvertent sexism. Not having it in that chamber.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for this SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and unafraid. "The Story" with guest host Sandra Smith starts right now. Sandra?

END

urn:contentItem:5RVP-YCG1-F03R-N4J0-00000-00Cyberattacks using Microsoft PowerShell soar by over 400%2018-03-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:23ZLexisNexisCyberattacks using Microsoft PowerShell soar by over 400%

Mar 12, 2018( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) Microsoft's PowerShell scripting engine is becoming the target of choice for attackers looking to sneak exploits onto Windows systems. Research conducted by McAfee found the use of "fileless" hacking, using scripts instead of programs, is rapidly growing. PowerShell is a sophisticated scripting engine that's frequently used by system administrators to automate common management functions.

PowerShell provides command-line access to almost all features of a Windows computer, including software installation, process management, configuration editing and various code execution capabilities. The deep OS-level integration of PowerShell makes it an ideal scripting language for admins working with Windows PCs. This same characteristic also renders it a highly attractive target for cyberattackers, who can craft PowerShell scripts to interfere with a system, extract data and run malicious commands.As reported by ComputerWeekly[1], McAfee Labs found[2] adoption of PowerShell malware soared over the past year. The number of observed attacks rose by 432%, a figure that suggests cybercriminals are moving away from traditional file-based attack vectors. Compared with placing malicious executables on a machine, a PowerShell exploit may be harder to detect and easier to deploy.READ NEXT: Sir Tim Berners-Lee calls for "regulatory framework" for big tech[3]Attacks that have used PowerShell to infiltrate systems include several Microsoft Office threats, crypto-jacking software and the Operation Gold Dragon[4] campaign against the 2018 Winter Olympics. McAfee said the latter was an "exemplary" example of the possibilities of PowerShell malware. The company said the tool is rapidly becoming a "go-to" option for cyberattackers crafting malware designed to go unnoticed."In 2017, McAfee Labs saw PowerShell malware grow by 267% in Q4, and by 432% year over year as the threat category increasingly became a go-to toolbox for cybercriminals," said McAfee[5]. "The scripting language was irresistible, as attackers sought to use it within Microsoft Office files to execute the first stage of attacks."Mitigating PowerShell attacks can be difficult because the contents of malicious scripts can easily be obfuscated. Once it's running, a PowerShell script can disguise its operations and persist itself in a target system. Admins might not necessarily spot its existence, especially if they're already using legitimate PowerShell scripts on the same machine.Because PowerShell is preinstalled and enabled by default on Windows, attackers can count on it being always being available. McAfee said the best way to defend against script-based invasions is to provide training to users on spotting potential attacks. Most PowerShell malware is still distributed in regular spam emails, so users should remain vigilant when opening mail from unknown senders.
